docs.lead_paragraph: Smoking causes damage throughout the body by lowering levels of an enzyme key to physical and mental health, researchers reported today. Smoking is known to damage the lungs, heart and arteries, but PET scans show that it affects these organs as well as the kidneys and spleen by its effects on monoamine oxidase B, or MAO-B, the researchers said.

headline.main: Smoking Tied to Kidney and Spleen Damage

docs.abstract: Dr Joanna Fowler, Brookhaven National Laboratory (New York) researcher, and colleagues publish findings of PET scans on smokers and non-smokers in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences; scans show that Monoamine oxidase B, or MAO-B, is directly reduced throughout several organs, including kidneys and spleen; since MAO-B reducers are prescribed to treat depression, researchers conclude this reduction may influence addictive effects of smoking; some reduction in MAO-B is found throughout body, but full consequences are unknown (M)
docs.snippet: Smoking causes damage throughout the body by lowering levels of an enzyme key to physical and mental health, researchers reported today.     Smoking is known to damage the lungs, heart and arteries, but PET scans show that it affects these organs as...

keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

docs.lead_paragraph: Some music lovers carried the hepatitis A virus with them this year on the concert tours of their favorite bands, causing an outbreak of 25 cases involving residents of nine states, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The article, in the agency's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, noted that infections could be easily spread at these events, with thousands of people often camping in close proximity at sites where sanitary conditions sometimes are poor and unofficial food vendors are common.
docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention contends in Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report that hepatitis A has recently been spread through music tour followers; outbreak of 25 cases involving residents of nine states is linked to three jam bands; one group, String Cheese Incident, posted information about virus on website and got epidemiologists to vaccinate fans at their final concert events of season; epidemiologist Dr Priti Patel reports vaccinating about 300 fans (S)
docs.snippet: Some music lovers carried the hepatitis A virus with them this year on the concert tours of their favorite bands, causing an outbreak of 25 cases involving residents of nine states, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and...

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: New trauma reawakens old trauma, or so mental health professionals have often asserted. And in the aftermath of Sept. 11, many experts predicted that the terrorist attacks would exacerbate or rekindle psychiatric problems in people with a history of post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental illnesses, and increase the demand for psychiatric treatment. But a new study has found that the use of mental health services at medical centers run by the federal Department of Veterans Affairs in New York and Washington, the cities most directly affected, did not rise after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert Rosenheck, Veterans Administration Northeast Program Evaluation Center director, leads study published in American Journal of Psychiatry that finds tragic events of September 11 did not effect those already suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder any differently than rest of population; study also finds that use of mental health centers at medical centers run by federal Department of Veteran Affairs in New York and Washington did not rise after attacks as anticipated; smaller study, which contradicts findings, points out need for more study into causes of trauma related disorders (M)
docs.snippet: New trauma reawakens old trauma, or so mental health professionals have often asserted. And in the aftermath of Sept. 11, many experts predicted that the terrorist attacks would exacerbate or rekindle psychiatric problems in people with a history of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I received an exasperated call from a colleague who is a kind and skilled internist, begging me to see one of his patients. Despite her complaints, he could find nothing physically wrong with her, but she kept insisting on more medical tests. When I met his patient, she was emphatic that she didn't need a psychiatrist. ''This is real, and this is not in my head,'' she said. ''I can feel my heart beat constantly, and I'm afraid I'll have a heart attack.''

headline.main: When the Mind Tortures the Body With Illnesses Unseen

docs.abstract: Dr David Clark, University of Oxford researcher, publishes study in BMJ, British medical journal, that shows treating hypochondriacs with either cognitive therapy or stress management relieves their perceived pain better than leaving patient alone; hypochondria is described and crux question of whether sensations are real pain or imagined pain is analyzed; either answer does not undermine fact that hypochondriacs are hurting and more needs to be done to cure disorder; factitious disorder, where patients actually fake discomfort or self-inflict injury, is discussed; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: Not long ago, I received an exasperated call from a colleague who is a kind and skilled internist, begging me to see one of his patients. Despite her complaints, he could find nothing physically wrong with her, but she kept insisting on more medical...

docs.lead_paragraph: After decades on the rise, antibiotic use by American children fell by almost 25 percent from 1996 to 2000, according to a new study published in the journal Pediatrics. For the last several years, public health agencies have waged a campaign to reduce the use of antibiotics to treat viral infections and the overdiagnosis of ear infections in children. Children use more antibiotics than adults, and the increase in pediatric prescriptions has been linked to the development of drug-resistant strains of disease.
docs.abstract: Dr Jonathan A Finkelstein, Harvard Medical School researcher and lead author of study published in journal Pediatrics, finds antibiotic use for children has fallen by 25% since 1996; determines drop is due to fewer ear infections diagnosed, not just fewer prescriptions written; overuse of antibiotics in children has been linked to development of drug-resistant strains of illness; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: After decades on the rise, antibiotic use by American children fell by almost 25 percent from 1996 to 2000, according to a new study published in the journal Pediatrics.     For the last several years, public health agencies have waged a campaign to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Five to 10 years ago, most women having breast biopsies had open surgery, requiring general or local anesthesia and leaving visible scars. Now, in most cases, a surgeon inserts a thin needle to extract a sliver of tissue, leaving a tiny, virtually invisible, scar. Ten to 15 years ago, a prostate biopsy was performed with a thick rigid needle, surgery that required a hospital stay and came with risks of pain, bleeding, infection and other complications. Now, a surgeon inserts a thin needle and withdraws several strands of tissue while the patient is under light sedation.

headline.main: With Advances in Biopsies, Less Can Mean More

docs.abstract: Biopsies of almost any organ have undergone significant change over past 20 years; biopsies requiring surgeries are now almost entirely done without general anesthesia or hospital stays; new techniques, producing smaller tissue samples, more often require second opinion to determine diagnosis; samples, however, are being used in new ways to determine treatment effectiveness and glean more information about cancer itself; new techniques have not diminished need for highly trained pathologists and cytopathologists, who look at individual cells to determine possible malignancies; pathology techniques are described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Five to 10 years ago, most women having breast biopsies had open surgery, requiring general or local anesthesia and leaving visible scars. Now, in most cases, a surgeon inserts a thin needle to extract a sliver of tissue, leaving a tiny, virtually...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Katharine A. Phillips thought she knew a lot about mental illness. As a psychiatric resident at Harvard from 1988 to 1991, she was well versed in ailments like depression, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. But one day, when a distraught patient said his hair was the cause of all his misery, Dr. Phillips was stymied. Searching the psychiatric literature, she found references to an obscure diagnosis known as body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D. Its sufferers, she learned, are tormented by the notion that some part of their body -- hair, nose, skin, hips -- is ugly, abnormal or deformed, when it actually is not.

headline.main: Muting the Obsessions Over Perceived Flaws

docs.abstract: Dr Katharine A Phillips, McLean Hospital, Butler Hospital and Brown Medical School psychiatrist, discusses little known diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder, of which she is leading expert; contends 1 to 2 percent of population suffers from illness, which involves distorted self-image that is completely unfounded; difficulties in recognizing ailment and diagnostic clues for family and professionals are discussed; evidence shows BDD is at least partly biological as serotonin reuptake inhibitors help alleviate symptoms; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Katharine A. Phillips thought she knew a lot about mental illness. As a psychiatric resident at Harvard from 1988 to 1991, she was well versed in ailments like depression, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.     But one day, when a distraught...

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study indicates that the first National Alcohol Screening Day, observed four years ago at hundreds of sites nationwide, has been characterized a success, both in terms of attendance and results. More than 32,000 people attended the event in 1999, and two-thirds of a sample of participants surveyed later said they had quit drinking or cut back as a result.
docs.abstract: Dr Shelly F Greenfield, McLean Hospital (Belmont, Mass) researcher, publishes study in American Journal of Psychiatry that shows National Alcohol Screening Day, observed four years ago, had positive effect on many participants; out of 32,000 people who attended, two-thirds of those surveyed reported they had either quit drinking or cutback as result; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: A new study indicates that the first National Alcohol Screening Day, observed four years ago at hundreds of sites nationwide, has been characterized a success, both in terms of attendance and results.     More than 32,000 people attended the event in...

docs.lead_paragraph: People with asthma that gets worse at night might do well to avoid using melatonin as a sleep aid, according to a study issued yesterday. A hormone released by the pineal gland, melatonin plays a role in setting the body's circadian clock.
docs.abstract: Dr E Rand Sutherland, National Jewish Medical and Research Center (Denver) associate, publishing his study in Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, finds nocturnal asthma sufferers have substantially decreased lung function when melatonin levels are higher than normal; suggests avoiding melatonin supplements commonly used to aid sleep if nighttime asthma is present; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: People with asthma that gets worse at night might do well to avoid using melatonin as a sleep aid, according to a study issued yesterday.    A hormone released by the pineal gland, melatonin plays a role in setting the body's circadian clock.

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF ALLERGY AND CLINICAL IMMUNOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of suffering with stress urinary incontinence, an annoying and embarrassing disorder that forced her to shun her favorite activities and think twice even before lifting a heavy bag of groceries, Gloria Rose of Wellesley, Mass., wants the world of fellow sufferers to know there are ways to curtail this distressing problem. Six months ago Ms. Rose underwent a relatively simple operation -- installation of a vaginal sling to support her urethra against increases in abdominal pressure -- to correct the problem that afflicts as many as one woman in three and a much smaller number of men.

headline.main: Back in the Saddle, Confident and Diaperless

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column shares success story of 56-year-old Gloria Rose, who has overcome her stress urinary incontinence through relatively new surgical procedure known as tension-free vaginal tape sling placement; condition is often not diagnosed because women are too embarrassed to discuss it with their doctors and treatment options remain somewhat unknown even to medical professionals; factors, some of which include having been pregnant, age, obesity and smoking, can increase chances of becoming incontinent; nurse practitioner Diane K Newman, University of Pennsylvania division of urology, writes in American Journal of Nursing that majority of cases of incontinence could be improved through strenghthening of pelvic floor muscles; Kegel exercisesare discussed; procedures and surgeries available to help treat incontinence are enumerated; drawing (M)
